title.rendered: Facts you Must know Before Installing a Solar Panel

content.rendered:
Generally, solar energy provides homeowners and businesses with a steady and efficient power system whose services are far better than fossil fuel systems. Within the satisfaction of an efficient solar system, solar panel plays an important part in providing and sustaining solar energy needs. Solar panels are becoming increasingly popular among homeowners seeking to reduce their carbon footprint and lower energy costs. While solar panels provide significant long-term savings and environmental benefits, they may require a substantial upfront investment.

Several factors can be considered when investing in solar panels. To avoid being off the fence during the planning period of acquiring solar panels for your solar installation needs, it is important to consider the weather conditions in your area, the angle of your roof, your average monthly energy consumption, and how long you plan to reside in your current home. Before installation, it is essential to thoroughly research the various financing options available and familiarize yourself with the policies of your local utility company.

10 Factors to Consider Before Installing a Solar Panel

  • Roof Condition

The condition of your roof plays a crucial role in the initial stages of installing solar panels. If your roof is old or damaged, it may be necessary to repair or replace it before installing to avoid future disruptions. Regarding the materials used for the roof, sturdy options such as metal, tile, slate, and asphalt shingles are highly recommended due to their durability and suitability for solar panel installation.

In addition to the roof’s condition and materials, the positioning of the panels is equally significant. South-facing roofs receive the maximum sunlight throughout the day and year, making them ideal for solar panel installation. However, roofs facing east and west can also capture sufficient sunlight, albeit with a slight decrease in efficiency. It is also important to consider the angle of your roof. Generally, an angle ranging from 35 to 45 degrees is considered optimal for maximizing sun exposure.

  • Sun Exposure

The quantity of sunlight that reaches your residence directly impacts the efficiency of your solar panels in generating energy. Regions like the southwestern United States, which receive abundant sunshine throughout the year, greatly benefit from solar power. However, solar energy remains a viable option even in less sunny areas. Modern solar panels can produce electricity from indirect sunlight, even on overcast or foggy days. It is important to be mindful of potential obstructions that may cast shadows on your solar panels, as they can significantly diminish energy production. Structures, trees, and other objects that block sunlight during peak hours can reduce the effectiveness of your solar panels.

  • Current Energy Usage

Understanding your energy consumption is crucial in determining the appropriate size of the solar panel system. Higher electricity usage will require more panels to meet those needs. A reliable installer will provide an estimate of the cost per watt. A household’s energy needs are a significant factor in deciding the type of solar panel setup, whether for partial or complete disconnection from the main power grid. Opting for off-grid living will necessitate the installation of additional and more efficient solar panels to fulfill all energy requirements. It is advisable to use high-quality equipment even when utilizing solar energy as an alternative power source.

  • Cost

Considering the installation costs when incorporating solar systems into your home is important. Investing in a solar panel system can reduce your electricity expenses over the years, eventually paying for itself through savings. The total cost can vary depending on system size, type, location, and installation complexity. Fortunately, many governments offer rebates and tax incentives to promote the adoption of renewable energy sources.

Research your area’s available incentives, grants, and subsidies thoroughly. These incentives may decrease over time, so there may be benefits to installing solar panels sooner rather than later.

  • Solar Panel Brands

Choosing a reputable solar company offers numerous benefits. Companies that provide high-quality equipment will likely offer warranties and regular system maintenance. Some companies even offer extended warranty periods, up to 10 years in some cases. Additionally, they have the expertise to carry out professional installations of the systems. Researching and selecting the best company for the job is crucial. A recommendation from a satisfied customer can be particularly valuable.

  • Type of Solar Panels

There are various solar panel options for homeowners to select from on the market. These options consist of mounted solar panels, movable panels, and shingles.

Mounted panels are the most prevalent and favoured type of solar panels. They are constructed using silicon, which comes in different levels of efficiency and cost. The monocrystalline silicon panels, known for their high efficiency, have a longer lifespan but are also more expensive. Monocrystalline panels are characterized by their sleek black colour, which enhances their efficiency as black surfaces naturally absorb more light. Factors such as the available roof space, budget, aesthetic preferences, and desired energy output may influence your decision.

  • Your Location

The optimal number and type of solar panels for your property are heavily influenced by its location. It is crucial to consider the amount of direct sunlight your location receives, as this directly affects the panels’ energy output. Living in the southern or southwestern regions provides a significant advantage in harnessing solar energy due to abundant sunlight. However, it is important to be aware that tall buildings and trees surrounding your house can block the sunlight and decrease the efficiency of your panels. Therefore, it is essential to ensure that your panels are exposed to full sunlight to maximize energy production.

  • Maintenance

Solar panels require maintenance, such as occasional cleaning and regular inspection. It is important to clearly understand the maintenance required, especially considering the specific location. For example, panels may require more frequent cleaning to maintain performance in a dusty environment or area with heavy snowfall.

  • Backup System

The choice of implementing a backup system is greatly influenced by your connection to the local utility grid or your decision to disconnect from it. Remaining connected to the grid enables you to access power when your solar panels are not generating enough electricity, such as during nighttime or overcast days. Moreover, it allows you to sell surplus energy to the grid, earning credits on your electricity bill in regions with net metering policies. On the other hand, investing in a solar battery storage system may be worth considering if you opt for an off-grid setup or seek energy independence during grid failures.

  • Durability

Solar panels must be highly durable to withstand weather conditions, including high winds, hail, and heavy snow. It is crucial to consider the lifespan of the systems when purchasing them before installation. Engaging licensed companies for the supply and installation offers more advantages as they provide high-quality equipment with extended warranties, indicating that the solar systems are built to last. Superficial assessment of the systems without delving into the manufacturing specifics can result in installing subpar equipment that may be faulty in the future.

Conclusion

The installation of solar panels represents a major financial and environmental investment, offering the possibility of significant returns. Nevertheless, it is a decision that should be made with time, as thorough research is essential.
